citation.article-title: Clostridium grantii sp. nov., a new obligately anaerobic, alginolytic bacterium isolated from mullet gut.

p.s: Description of Clostridium grantii sp. nov.
Clostridium grantii (named in honour of William Donaldson Grant for his contribution to our understanding of marine polysaccharide degradations)
Clostridium grantii is obligately anaerobic; cells are motile, sporulating, slightly curved rods (0.6μm wide and 3.5 to 7.0μm long) and are gram-positive.
Cell walls contain the peptidoglycan component meso-diaminopimelic acid.
The organism derives energy for growth by fermenting alginate, and hexose mono- and disaccharides, to form acetate, ethanol, formate, and CO2.
No lactate, propionate, butyrate, succinate, or H2 is produced as fermentation end products.
No reduction of NO3- or S042- occurs during fermentations.

Lactose, galactose, sucrose, dulcitol, carrageenan, agar, laminarin, cellulose, xylan, fucoidin, isoleucine, valine, esculin, fumarate, lactate, glycerol, malate, yeast extract, and casamino acids are not utilized as substrates for growth.
The pH range for growth is 5.5 to 8.0 and the pH optimum is 6.5.
The temperature range for growth is 17 to 45°C and the optimum growth temperature is 30°C.
The salinity range for growth is 1 to 10/103.
The DNA base ratio is 30.2mol% G+C.
The organism was isolated from mullet gut contents.
